reviewText:
Defiance is something of an anomaly in the MMO space. It is at once massively multiplayer, a third-person Shooter, and an Action-RPG in the vein of Borderlands. Its setting and story are also tied to a Syfy network television show that could markedly increase the game's depth. Defiance is also daring. As the first MMO to launch simultaneously on PC and consoles, it claims a first for the genre. In short, the game ventures into unproven yet well inspired territory. The question, then, is whether Defiance ever actually develops into something unique and worth returning to. The answer is yes but with some caveats.
You play the role of an Arkhunter: a souped up, AI-enabled treasure hunter. Your “goal” is to search out alien technology to help return the world to its former, pre-alien invasion state. Very little is explained as the game opens. All you know is that you are returning to Earth on a space freighter and are shot down. But from where and by who? You meet a scientist with an “Ark Core” and he explains that it will help him restore the planet, but how it will do so is left a mystery. When you crash land, the pieces start to come together, but ever so slowly.
As you progress through the game's story missions, the shroud begins to lift but it feels drip fed and late. The narrative in Defiance attempts to emulate the bread crumb model of television delivery, flush with mission-based cutscenes and full voice acting, but without background it feels hackneyed.
On the surface, Defiance looks much like any other sci-fi shooter. Your travel by foot, ATV, or car, meeting soldiers and survivors in a terra-formed and nearly unrecognizable San Francisco Bay. You kill mutant soldiers and Hellbugs and, if you're anything like me, occasionally take your vehicle on a bit of a tear and launch yourself from hillsides. Then the RPG-inspired and elemental-tinged weapons appear, and you begin to notice the masses of other people chipping away at missions, and the similarities begin to shed.
Defiance’s two key selling points are its vast array of weaponry and its dynamic content. As you venture through the game, you will come across firearms ranging from pistols to LMGs and grenade launchers. Many of these have special attributes such as damage-over-time modifiers or stuns. The “infector” for instance, is an automatic pistol that causes parasites to burst from fallen enemies. My current favorite, is a shotgun that electrocutes my enemies, snaring them for a few extra blasts.
Arkfalls are the most prominent form of dynamic content. Similar to RIFT's rifts. In these random public events, rocks fall from the sky and waves of enemies swarm forth culminating in a final boss battle. At the end of these, all participants are ranked on a leaderboard and rewarded by contribution. Sometimes Arkfalls come in sets throughout a region requiring that you defeat several in a row. As you venture through the world, you may come across other, more subdued events, such as saving a group of ranchers from raiders or an EMT vehicle from a mutant ambush.
At its core, Defiance follows a traditional MMO progression model, notably lacking levels and classes. Completing missions earns experience and money which are then used to upgrade and outfit your character. In lieu of rating players by level, Defiance uses something called an EGO rating with which you unlock perks. In practice this system is simply levels by another name. Players still receive power boosts at regular intervals. Perks can also have a profound impact each player's aptitude on the battlefield.
Defiance uses engaging episode missions to advance the story. These feature characters from the show with full voice acting and cinematic storytelling. You will infiltrate bunkers, take over cell towers, plant tracking devices to find lost citizens or wipe out Hellbugs that have infested farmer's fields. The missions are varied, entertaining, and make the game worth playing. Side missions are a different story. They are plainly excuses to get you into combat. Often located on the side of the road, you kill mutants or bugs or tag dead bodies. They are disappointingly repetitive and if the shooting model were any worse, I would have called them boring.
Challenges, however, are unique. These missions are instanced, objective-based, and repeatable with the goal of earning a high score on the leaderboard. Playing well rewards you with experience and money but the real allure is asynchronous competition. Tasks generally require killing enemies against a timer, surviving waves with a special weapon, or racing vehicles through checkpoints. Although fun, challenges seem more like a diversion than a core gameplay feature.
Competitive multiplayer works well, even if it is disappointingly sparse. As with many MMOs, there are some balance issues that players have to deal with. Leveling players will naturally be at a disadvantage to those with higher EGO ratings but the differences aren't game-breaking. A skilled beginner could trounce an unawares veteran but at the most basic level, a more experienced player simply has more perks and better gear.
While Defiance nails its most important qualities, it misses others entirely. Trion earns the record of being the first MMO launch to launch simultaneously on three platforms, but in order to accomplish that feat there is an unmistakable feeling that the PC version is an afterthought. There are bugs, missing features, and a user interface that feels cut and pasted from its console edition. To put it in perspective, Trion Worlds is the same company that sold RIFT by trumpeting their vast MMO experience. Even though the development teams are different, this paltry port job is inexcusable from a publisher who has told us, literally, that they know better.
ESC key to open the main menu actually closes the game for some players. The game can be unresponsive or even minimize itself. Core features are missing, such as the ability to take a screenshot or open an actual mission log. Even something as basic as chat is far from functional. Quests glitch, often with NPCs getting stuck on terrain. Enemies spawn in odd, out of the way places. Trion has taken steps to correct some of these issues but many still remain.
At its core, Defiance is an exceptionally fun game but its shortcomings can be craterous. Defiance lacks the humor of Borderlands but retains all of the gun-hunting and combat that made that game great but the bugs and interface issues are a problem. Patches will surely address these but that does not take away from the fact that the game suffers for its week-one presentation. Even with the solid core to pick it back up, it may be difficult to convince people to come back. If you can get through its shortcomings, Defiance is well worth a look.

reviewText:
This is probably the best shooter MMO out there.  The community is actually nice (when they can type!) and people listen and respond.  The action is crazy fun, the vehicles are fun to drive too.. getting air off a big hill is awesome.

And the weapons.. so many different types and all with their own upgradable parts that each of their own stats.

It's definitely worth a try (It's free to play, so.. why not?).

EDIT:  Just to add a few things:  The show crossover is getting really interesting.  You don't have to know anything about the show to be able to play the game, but it's pretty cool to recognize the races and some of the people in the game as also being in the TV Show.

I have to say also, after playing Firefall for awhile.. Defiance is truly a superior game in every regard.  The only thing you can do in Firefall that you can't do in Defiance is fly.. if you put points in the right area.  And all that gets you is a few less hits from melee mobs and a whole lot more hits from ranged.

There really is no better shooter MMO out there.  And with all the new content they add pretty much weekly, Defiance is growing and changing all the time.

reviewText:
A cult favorite of mine, and the first MMO to ever coincide with a live-action TV show, Defiance is a unique MMO to say the least. Trion Worlds is most famous for there other MMO, Rift, however Defiance features a unique blend of open-world combat, free-roaming and large scale boss fights. In terms of weapons, think of Borderlands. Defiance has hundreds if not thousands of different weapons, shields, and more.

The game also sports a vast collection of vehicles to chose from including a limited edition 2013 Dodge Charger specifically designed for the vast and rugged terrains of Defiance. There is also a huge amount of character creation, including tons of in game armour's along with some purchasable items such as hats, armour's, shields and more. The grind is real, but it's not a big issue in Defiance because the ranking system is fairly balanced and easy to rank up.

I'll admit that the quests are a bit repetitive feeling, but the overall game is very enjoyable and it remains in my top 5 MMO's I have played thus far.

reviewText:
If Borderlands and Gears of War had a baby, and WoW and Planetside had a baby, and then those two babies had a baby. This would be that baby.

This game does feel like it was developed for  potatoes console, which it was. But still a fun game overall. Tired of playing an MMO and looking for a raid group for hours? Good, you don't need to wait in this game. Arkfalls happen dynamically and scale based on the amount of people that show up to do it. Whether its just you, or 50 other people trying to kill the big dudes, the challenge stays the same.

Individual gear drops are awesome, nobody steals your loot, and the loot that drops is always geared towards your level. If you find baller gear at level 100, you can keep leveling it up with you to 4000+ if you farm (or buy) the arkstuff to level it up.

Overall, I'd say 8/10. Better than most MMOs I spent 50+ bucks +subscription on.

reviewText:
Defiance is a great example of what free to play is capable of and what it should be. Literally only 5 restrictions for free to play members and none of it makes an impact on how you want to play and beat the game. This is a very unique game that adds free missions for each episode of the TV series that comes out adding more content to a game that is packed with missions and sidequest to do. THe game has so much lore and interesting races you want to find out about but leaves you wanting more. Now when this game first came out it didn't have half the content it does now and people that shelled out 60 for it might have felt smited. But the game has come a long way since its release and rewards those who paid for it by getting a bunch of extra goodies that help them progress faster then f2p members. Music and sound is decent but mostly forgettable also voice acting is not very good but some funny lines. This game has hundreds of hours of content that can keep you very busy but alot of the missions might feel the same and repeat a bit along with the daily arkfalls. . Grouping up with your friends is extremely fun and even has a go to friend option never being left behind. Defiance shows up other MMO's that it is possible to have perfect controller support. Community is very friendly and often revives you if near. The PvP is a really interesting concept but can't hold up on this game or its engine due to overpowered wepons and unbalanced ego abilities. Easily the best part about this game is its gun and looting system. There are hundreds maybe thousands of different guns to buy loot find upgrade or even be given to after a mission. With all different stats colors abilities there are so many combinations it's unreal on par with Borderlands. I will actually say the guns here are better then the Borderland series cause the guns actually all look different not just different colors. THey have everything form pistols to infection guns that spawn headcrabs and parasites on enimies. The only thing holding this game back besides its PvP would be the servers. They are constantly adding updates or tweaking things so the servers go wonky often reulting in disconnections, severe glitches, and other characters all looking the same. In the end some of the missions get repetitive server issues often and PvP is lacking. It is defintely a game you should check out and invest a little time into.


Final score 7/10

reviewText:
This game is great. This game makes you team up with complete strangers, whether you like it or not. If you go solo for, say an  Arkfall, you will die. If you go with a dozen people (which is almost guarenteed with Arkfall Sites, especially Major ones), you will have a higher chance.

This game has little to none glitches and bugs for me. The only one I've encountered is throwing me off my car as it disapears while I'm riding it. Other then that, I haven't found anything.

I am rather picky when it comes to PvE games. I enjoyed PlanetFall until the major update, and then I never looked back. This game, has yet to dissapoint me. With a great storyline, level up system, and weapons, this is one of my favorite PvE games so far.  The Sword is pretty awesome too.

Let's talk about EGO Rating. EGO Rating works so that you earn X ammount of EGO for certain things. Level up? 10 EGO! Finish a pursuit? 5 EGO! etc. This is a rather creative twist to this game. EGO Rating is required to have more Perk slots, loadouts, and to upgrade your EGO Power. This, along with leveling up system, makes this a favorite for me.

Leveling up system you say? This games Leveling up system puts you in a square/rectangle, with one of 4 Ego powers in each corner. The rest is filled with perks. You pick one Ego Power in the beginnning of the game, and if you want another one, you need to build across the grid, grabbing perks until you reach the power of your desire.

Lets talk about Arkfalls. Arkfalls are special side missions where you need to do a certain quest. Defeat 3 waves, break a crystal, etc. Then, you get the Arkfall SItes previously mentioned. These put you inside a Arkfall, fighting off enemies. There are 2 Arkfall SItes: Minor and Major. Minor ones send you in, you kill some people and bam! uncommon loot, with a rare chance of rare. However, Major Sites send you into the Arkfall, and going deeper inside to fight a creature. You get much better loot, and a bunch of xp. I have only found 1 Major during my 8 hours of playing, which I consider myself lucky to find. I have, however, particapated in multiple Minor Site raids.

All in all, this game is absolutely amazing. 17000/10. Make sure to buy it during the Winter Sale, as it is only $5 right now.
voteText: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I would not reccommend this game as a long term form of entertainment. The storyline is trash. So incredibly bland and uninteresting. You dont benefit at all from playing the storyline missions, either. There is no incentive to do the missions because you get really crappy weapons. Once you get a few good weps, you pretty much learn to ignore everything else.

The gameplay is pretty robust, but the missions are extremely repetitive. All you do is kill enemies (all of them) or go interact with objects in order to complete missions. Playing with friends makes it fun, but there doesnt seem to be a clear method of actually doing missions together. You can form groups and clans but there isn't much explanation on how to do other group activities.

The most fun events were the Arkfalls becasue they were so chaotic and so many people were playing at once ( easily 60-80 players at once, with little lag!!). However, there is not much variation with them. They are all pretty much the same.

PvP was put together as an afterthought, it seems. They realized they could re-use all their previously build mechanics and only have to make a few extra TDM and CP maps. Its really not that fun, unfortunately. The Shadow War looked cool, as it allows a 64 vs 64 open world match. Unfortunately, I've never played with more than 20 people at once. The co-op is also very bland.

The interface of the game is pretty much ported from a console. Buttons look like list items and things that are supposed to be clickable dont look like i can click them.The chat is a joke because a.) nobody really uses it and b.) as a 3rd person shooter, you are shooting and playing the game looking at your crosshair and enemies most of the time. People were trying to get my attention in game and I had no idea because the chat window was completely hidden except for a transparent blue bar. I messed up some missions because I didn't know people were talking to me. Really got under my skin.

Anyway, it actually has a better feel on a console. I played it on PS3 too.

It seems really cool at first. You're gonna love it at first. Play it for a little while and learn how things work before you drop money.

reviewText:
Defiance has gone through a few changes since when it was first revealed. For some, the game was lackluster but they enjoyed the three season long TV series. For others, they prefered the game over the show.

Either way, there aren't that many third-person MMO shooters available on the market and the game does a decent job of being one of your options. The way you can group up with others as you're doing a mission or world event and leave to do your own thing, all without having to go through the UI to form parties is nice, and how enemy encounters scale based on the number of surrounding individuals is a good mechanic as well.

The only thing that'll likely cause new players to have a rocky start is how weapons can have nano effects which allow for more damage based on the type of enemy they're fighting - For example, bio is preferred against enemies with high armor plating while electrical deals the most damage to the shields of an enemy.


Besides that, the game is free and can be enjoyed without the DLC. If you choose to get them, you'll have access to a third race, ability to call down arkfalls, and a bunch of minor things that don't really detract from the main game. No harm in giving it a look if you want to shoot things from a different perspective.

reviewText:
When I first played this game I thought it was pretty fun. Also I expected that there would be more content released but  I was wrong.
There are essentially only 3 enemies to fight all with bad AI.
The environment is pretty but gets boring very quickly. Questing is very tedious and redundant.
Game feels like a watered down co-op version of borderlands. Honestly it feels like the game is missing half of its initial content, this is an obvious money grab and it's just not worth your time even in this F2P form with microtransactions.

4/10

reviewText:
If you like Borderlands, then you will love this game! If you hated Borderlands, you still might want to give this a try because it has everything that Borderlands lacks.
Defiance is a post apocalyptic game where humans and aliens try to live in peace on a Earth that has been so vastly changed by terraforming and everything isn't completely made of tin roofs and signs. You play as an ArkHunter and your main job is to complete missions for NPCs. You can also do side missions and challenges, they are fairly fun but do get repetitive after a bit. There are also missions called ArkFalls, a gaint crystal falls from the sky and either mutants or Hellbugs are around it. After the typical 3 waves of badies are gone collect all the goodies on the ground and stuff your inventory. Its a pretty decent challenge if you play alone but its much more fun and a bit more difficult if you play with a huge group of players.
If you'd like to play with a friend, its so easy to team up! I always play games where I co-op and i gotta say, this was extremely easy to connect to. For me, there is very little waiting time for things and smaller areas to load. The game play is pretty smooth although it can glitch up a bit (a main mission's enemies wouldnt appear once for us but it did come back the next day).
I find the controls to be very smooth and very easy to move around. Even the driving is pretty smooth, on the road at least! you can take your vehicles off-road and its one heck of a ride. There are some ramps and cut off roads that are awesome to jump off of. Just be careful of rocks and road blocks, you'll either get stuck or explode and be ejected from you vehicle into a horde of badies.
The guns aim well and are easy to control but it can be overwhelming trying to find the right gun for yourself and applying mods.
Often times you'll have more weapons and grenades than you'll know what to do with. Its a bit confusing and a lot of trial and error and you will have to sell a lot of items but at least you make a lot of ingame money. Although you can buy things with real world money i really didn't see the need to spend money on in game stuff.
This game is so much fun and for the price, i feel very satisfied and to me it is very worth the money (mine was a gift though, thanks Vader!).  I usually never write reviews to games but this one truly deserves to be reconized for its great game play, good story and the amount of hours you'll spend on it.

reviewText: Defiance has been fun so far, you can play alone and do missions solo or team up in a group to do them, i would say its more fun to play as a group but not totally needed. Graphics are clear enough and gameplay is easy. There are however some issues like not being able to log in, getting kicked out, game crashes but i kinda expect that these days with any online game as none are perfect, Do you have to watch the tv series before playing? i would say it helps if you want to follow the story and understand but not really important if you just want a fun online shooter with some friends. All in all despite its problems i would say its not a bad buy for the price and on sale well worth it and hopefully the developers will keep supporting this game for as long as possible as with good support it could be excellent. PS Peacekeeper signing off..........

reviewText: I was first bitten by the Free to Play model a few years ago and have not looked back since.  I have tried many games at this point and have seen them run the gambit.  Defiance contains the polish and content that is worth your time.  I played for many hours before opting to reward the developers with some of my cash.  Note is was not necessary for gameplay or needed for progression.  Defiance has an interesting story line that piqued my curiosity enough for me to check out a few episodes of Defiance on Amazon Prime, and plan on continuing to watch.  It is my understanding that there are codes given out at the end of each episode for free in games items.  These rewards are only given out during an active season and as we are in between seasons I am NOT able to verify this but am hopeful.  The game does not really hold your hand and the community is small so expect to have to figure some game play mechanics on your own.  I encountered some minor lag issues and quest bugs but I have not anything that is completely broken.  All in all this is one of the better Free to Play MMO’s out there.  Give it a try I think you will be pleasantly surprised!!

reviewText:
As a fan of the show, and of MMOs in general. I really wanted to like this game. I was pumped when the whole thing was announced. A sci fi MMO that ties in with a TV show?! Brilliant! What a great idea!  I tried, lord did I try, I even brought a few friends in who didn't last nearly as long as I did.

It only shows 0.5 hours played for me, but that's probably cause I uninstalled and reinstalled a couple times. I'v certainly put more than 100 hours into this. Probably closer to 200.

I don't have anything to point out that others haven't already. The game is repetitive and lacks anything original. It sucked me in at first, but once the questlines run out, you're basically just driving around the map looking for group events, a lot of the time, by the time you get there the group is finishing up and you missed out on most of the good action.

It's really not awful, it's just not a game you're gonna sink 300+ hours into. The reviews say mostly positive, but if you're looking for a game that's gonna hold your attention for a while. This is not it.

reviewText: This third person (over the shoulder) shooter is also an MMORPG. It incorporates skill-trees to upgrade your perks and it's incredibly fun using them. At first, buying this game was a nerve-racking experience because who wants to devote 10 bucks (at the time) to a game that you'll never play again. HOWEVER, after taking the chance, I was really impressed. The free-roam feel is amazing and I finding yourself in rough situations is something that can happen often if you go too far without help. Thankfully help can be given by random strangers passing by. It's challenging in some areas but enough to only make you wanna push for more, rather than rage. Figured I'd write something for this game since there are so few reviews on it. I hope you enjoy the game!

reviewText:
I've played it since initial release and it was and still is amazing.
Pros:
- vehicles (from ATVs to Trucks) with great navigation
- player customization (not only face/race but outfits/headgear too, with great variety)
- excellent weapons (from heavy machine guns to laser swords!) with visually improving mod attachments
- tv series crossover (it's really nice to meet TV heroes and fight side-by-side with them)
- great player voices and voice acting generally. Some great actors were cast in recurring roles.
I love the psycho male voice, he's like the Joker from Batman HAHAhehehihihihohohuehuehue!
- massive open world (one of the greatest parts about any videogames)
- creative enemy units (raiders, robots, insects, zombies and high-tech ninjas, they got'em all, of all sizes and shapes)
- great story/questline (and a lot of story-like maps in the lobby system)
- seamless co-op! (and great PvP for who likes this sort of thing)
- constant events and ballanced leveled up
- interesting, satisfying, colorful graphics with a solid post-apocalyptic vibe

Cons:
- can feel lonely if you don't play with a friend.
- can be difficult to get legendary item drops
- some random encounters can be overwhelming (dying a lot a lot) if you don't have enough participants to have your back.
- can be difficult to manage inventory space (I have about 4-5 legendaries I don't use but don't feel like I should drop or destroy either). but yeah, my inventory is always stacked.
- player-to-player trading can be difficult to do unless you join 3rd party sites and even then you may not have takers
- after about 300 hours or so can become repetitive, yet events can refresh the feel of it
- the new implants/perks things is a bit complicated, but after you get it, you get it.
- Story/new Content DLCs are still expensive. I'm hoping for a 7th Legion discount still :P

Bottom line: Get it! Play the hell out of it! Enjoy this awesome San Francisco Bay area and ride the wheels off of the vehicles! Also, get a sword and slam the ground! Also, get a sniper rifle :D Also, if you want legendaries, look me up!

reviewText: Smooth and sweet! I have to admit. I was EXCEPTIONALLY skeptical of this game and tried the free trial thinking I would hate it, and end up uninstalling it. I had just uninstalled Neverwinter, a title run by the same company that made another mmorpg. They used allot of elements in their first mmorpg (Star Trek) in Neverwinter and it felt so bad and horribly cloned I could not stand it. In TRION's Defiance, I was very worried I would be playing RIFT like character models. However, it was NOT the case. I was very surprised at how smooth the character was moving around and how engaging the story was. There are cutscenes and an over all story arc that pulls you into the world and makes it feel living.\nThere is an opening cutscene very egaging and interesting to watch. It ties in fluidly to introduce your character and put you right into the mmorpg open world. This is a hard concept most developers CANNOT pull off. If you read my Neverwinter review, you would see how I was so dissapointed that the game has a great system of cinematics mixed with in game gameplay for the first 5 levels, then abruptly cuts off and leaves you with rinse and repeat quest hubs and over all compelling story. In fact, most games are like this. Or you do a bunch of meangless tasks to hit that one point in the game that unlocks a small video file to show you what is going. But it feels awaward at best and interuptive and more of a reward" for reaching this point in the game.\nIn defiance
date: this is not the case. The movie starts and then the action and what happens next and how the movie cuts in the game is SUPER fluid with everything you interact with. I was so impressed with how this made up the world that as an FPS and as an MMORPG this out performed almost all games I have been testing over the years. Especially the F2P... I am just blown away at the quality and detail used to create the "I am here
hoursPlayed: and it is important" feel of the game. The publisher uses NPCs that mix right in with the cinematic scenes. It is very generous to give the story telling in a smooth

reviewText:
This game looks decent enough to try but after spending a couple days playing it, it no longer is a decent game but a terrible game. The game has been out for over a year according to wiki but this game has tons of bugs with 4 DLC with a 5th suppose to be released.

The game mechanics are broken in that since you're actually required to shoot the mobs, the mobs love to teleport due to glitches. Kinda hard to hit mobs when they teleport around. You carry limited ammo and if you choose sniping, you will quickly find yourself out of ammo or praying that you take down the mob in 4-5 head shots(not kidding about the amount of headshots). Instances are not bound by walls so if you were to get knocked over anytype of short barriers and into the water, you will die or spend 10 minutes getting back into the area if you are able to get up the shore.

The community is worse in that nobody really communicates in this game other than if you are in a clan. You are limited to only type in chat when you are at the main play screen, not the loadout menu or any other menu. You can't skip cutsceens and will repeat cutsceeens regardless of the amount of times you are redoing an instance.

There is no actual player class. That is the only good thing going for this game except good luck getting a great weapon for the style you want to play. Some of the other weapons are broken and will not even damage mobs on explosion.

reviewText:
Defiance is definitely an interesting game.  The storyline starts off well, but I felt somewhat cut off from what exactly was going on.  I progressed, I participated in collective, massive battles of 50-100 people, I participated in the instance levels that came with the game.  It is definitely an TPS and it works well for the shooting part.

However, if you haven't watched the show this is based upon, then you will definitely lose out.  I have not watched the show, and I barely knew what exactly was going on.  The military was involved somehow, and the sidequests made very little sense.  Some of the missions were super difficult for 1 player in story mode.  And I was armed to the teeth with grenades and assault rifles.  What really ticked me off is that I would kill enemies in my story instance, use up all my grenades doing so, one person survives and kills me off.  What happens?  The story instance restarts with all the enemies coming back alive to full health and ammo.  Except I have no grenades and no ammo.  Every time I had to restart, the story instance would restart and I would not.  This happened many times, and eventually I was spending an hour on a simple mission, because I had to kill every enemy all over with next to no ammo and grenades.

The massive battles were interesting, but there were no rewards other than shared xp (amongst a hundred people).  Also turns out I can explore the whole map at any level, and there is literally nothing that interested me landmark wise.  Everything is almost the same everywhere.  The skills were decently thought out, and the skills as well as the lack of lag and graphical distortion were really the only positives for me.

Don't get me wrong, if you enjoy TPS and you have a few other friends who like 'em and you wanna just fool around in an MMO with guns, then maybe this could be a game to do so in.  But it loses it's fun very fast.  In my personal opinion, it was not worth the buy.

reviewText: Defiance's greatest problems are the complete lack of variations, and a progression system that feels like you're not progressing at all. You'll soon realise that there's basically less than a dozen different missions which you repeat over and over again, and that gets old VERY quickly, even though it's fun in the beginning. It also has one of the worst UIs I've ever seen, I can only remember FFXIV's (first version) as an example of something worse.\n\nDon't waste time on this, pretty much everything else out there beats this game.

reviewText:
This game showed a lot of promise originally and reminded me of an open-world Phantasy Star Online so I was riding on a nostalgia high horse when I started playing Defiance. I liked the story missions and even went out of the way to do all the side missions. I liked the lack of the MMO Trinity in dungeons and the PvP was refreshing with a choice of instanced or open world.

I bought the game for several friends in fact and we all enjoyed it together.

2-3 weeks later you've pretty much done everything the game has to offer a few times and up to a dozen times and more of other certain aspects and all the magic is gone. The show is suppose to time in to the game and vice versa but that's all but vanished and died.

They did add some melee weapons as well so updates are still happening but at an incredibly slow rate (maybe 1-2 a year given current track record) and none of these really add any content for the endgame.

If you're looking for something to last you the weekend than by all means get the game, it'll occupy your time nicely.

But, if you're expecting something you can keep coming back to? Look elsewhere.

reviewText:
I played AMB 3 (Advanced Mission Beta 3 or whatever) and I have come to say I like it, yet not. Here are some things below that I think need changing...

Bug Fixes
FIXED >> * When you restore functionality to each secondary radio tower (KTAM East, West, South) you fall from the sky after the cutscene.
* Sometimes, bullets don't hit targets. (Especially noticeable with manual sniper rifles.)
* Sometimes, shots that should be missed, hit.

Things to Improve
* Textures. They look okay for mid-HD range, but not high-end HD (1080p+) range where they can have washed out edges, etc.
* The sun. It's basically a blurry blob when at the edges of the horizon.
* Render Distance of players and enemies. I don't like how enemies and players look like they're slo-mo / lagging at large distances. That said, sniper rifles are useless when trying to see enemies far off, because the render distance for entities is so low.
* Culling. Get rid of it.
* Enemy AI Line of sight. It pains me to note that cloaking gets rid of aggro, yet going behind buildings doesn't reduce aggro when alone at all. Come on guys, we aren't Minecraft.

Things to add
* Unique skills / etc. for each class chosen. For instance, the machinist could have an activated skill that places a dispenser of sorts similar to that of Team Fortress 2 so that players don't have to go all the way to the nearest ammo refill point. Veterans could have a passive that makes them better at LMG spread (more accuracy) without the need for perks.
* An auction house system to trade directly from scrip to bits and vice versa. As well as an auction house to bid / buy out items / mods, etc. The AH would be a stand-alone EGO via a holographic emitter of sorts in each major NPC village (including the starting one near the crash site.)
* An explicit mod attachment tutorial.

reviewText:
Really not bad. It's MMO Borderlands.

I mean, seriously, it's a direct rip of the Borderlands gameplay, online, in third-person. It even has the weird disembodied robot girl leading you around by the nose, and the awkward moon jump (which Borderlands has because you're on a small moon, while this game is set on Earth...?)

It's a fun game. It has some serious balance problems, but overall it has nice graphics, huge open areas, enjoyable shooter gameplay, and you can poop an ATV anywhere and ride it around like it's GTA. So it has that going for it. Also it's FREE now, so there's that too.

reviewText:
DefianceI really like playing this game! Defiance is now a free to play game so no investment other than your time is needed to play and enjoy this game.  I initially purchased Defiance while looking for something new to play with my family.  I did not have any expectations for this game and had never seen the Scify TV series, but I was surprised to see that even my wife liked it and she normally will not play a shooter, even if it is an MMORPG.

Game DesignDefiance has a lot of good design features with it like dungeon/pvp grouping tools as well as a limitless questing network.  The game uses a feature for looting similar to Rift, also a TRION Worlds game, in that you do not have to be grouped to receive loot from a kill.  The game uses Rift's rift (outdoor raid) feature but calls them ark falls.  The game also uses a system that allows players to play with others at any level and still receive xp and loot.  This is a double side coin that can make game play feel very repetitive.

The leveling prgress in the game are not your typical 1-50 levels.  In defiance you level to 5000, although I do not believe it takes any longer than the more traditional level design of 1-50.  With your levels you get points to develope your character's talents/trates/perks. Unlike other MMORPGs, Definace does little to specialize classes/races.  Other than the Castithan race which gets to use a dagger/sword melee weapon, there is nothing special about picking the race or class at the beginning of the game.

StoryDefiance's lore runs hand in hand with the popular TV series on the Syfy network.  The game and TV show writters/developers work with each other to make sure what one does, the other does as well. They even went as far a putting in a gamer's character into the show after holding a contest to pick the lucky gamer.

The GoodI really like the control and gameplay.  The loots system is great.  When doing an event or quest the item rewards are based on your level, not the zone.  The grouping system works very well for PvE and PvP.  The game is interwoven with the TV series.

The BadGraphically, the character models could look better.  The game engine is last gen.  Because the NPCs adjust to the level appropriate for the gamer so to speak, the game feels repetitive even when completing new quests. And last, there is no class specialization or specialized class missions so there is no value in leveling more than one character which limits replay value.

ConclusionDo I recommend it?  Absolutely!  It is a fun game that is now free to play so you have nothing to lose but the time investment of trying something new.

reviewText: I will let it be known i've bought this a few years since its launch so its not as bad for me as say people who had it  at launch but this game still has many flaws within its system and thats not even adding UI eyesores like the chat. Trion whatever the hell you were thinking it may have just screwed you because now as is this is barely even worth the 9.99 you brought it down too and i hope for both our sakes the gaming community learns from this. With that said if you are willing to buy it i assure you will at least get some fun out of it but definitely nowhere near what everyone was expecting before its release.

reviewText: In this game, you run from area to area shoothing things with no real objective, ever. You get experience based on how much damage you either heal or inflict. The amount of experience gained from healing is ridiculously higher than what you gain from dealing. The weapons you acquire are just garbage after a few levels, and based on the amount of damage you inflict creating a circular problem that is only solved if you sink money into this crappy, crappy game. The story line is horrid, and the reasons to keep playing are limited to a lack of anything better to do at the time.

reviewText:
Defiance is a Third Person Shooter action game with MMO elements. It features some fairly well done combat mechanics (namely, moving and shooting is pretty robust) and a full campaign. I've probably burned around 85 hours on it by now, and have a pretty high level character.
That being said, Defiance has a lot of problems that I can elaborate on.

1. Combat: The game can go from laughably easy to incredibly hard based on the drop of a hat. Wide, open free roaming environments can lead to long range combat to reach an objective, but then upon reaching the objective enemies spawn in point blank.  The shooting elements handle well, the enemy types can be fairly diverse, but with the exception of the very powerful Volge enemy types (think, large metal roboguys who can almost 4 shot you near the beginning of the game) enemies are kind of weak unless in very large numbers. The AI has some predetermined behaviors that are easy to learn and counter for, and occasionally you'll have a lot of fun fighting off multiple enemies at a time. However, the difficulty scales very inconsistently, often going from cakewalk to instant death depending on the location and mission.

2. Single Player Elements: Campaign missions are not consistent in their difficulty nor are they especially interesting after having done one of the four possible types of mission. These types essentially are Go here and push a button
hoursPlayed: "Go here and shoot some guys
voteText: grab a thing and come back"
helpfulPercent: "Go here and do this repeatable quest" and "Go here and do a minidungeon". The single player parts also offer a plot involving an "Ark Core" or whatever said plot-driver is and a few characters who are generic and underbuilt. Final boss is a refreshing dose of difficulty
votesHelpful: but is both too little and too late to make a huge impact.\n\n3. Multiplayer Elements: Coop and Competitive multiplay exist in Defiance. Coop modes have Dungeons and more Organic repeatable missions that reset periodically in the world. That being said
votesTotal: Coop tends to be incredibly easy for essentially the vast majority of the game's possible playable parts- save for one AND ONLY ONE segment- the Major Ark Fall that is called down by players buying a purchasable item through the Defiance store. This Major Ark Fall event features significant quantities of per-player scaling robobaddies ready to screw you up. That being said

reviewText: Okay I put quite a bit of time into the retail version of this game. It is a 3rd Person MMORPG which ties into the tv show of the same name. I enjoy it as it has an open world to explore, story missions, episode missions, arkfall events, competitive and co-op modes. The weapons are quite varied but they don't scale with level, although rarity can make a big difference, You pick an ego power but basically level up various perks. So a low level can balance against a high level. I find it fun and it reminds me a bit of Warhammer online, which was another under-rated game. Also you don't have to play it constantly to get the most out of it, but can just jump in for quick games.

reviewText:
Huge pro:
- The community. As you will drive around the desolate ruins of what used to be San Francisco, you will feel lonely. If you see any event on the map, go to it - you'll be amazed. No matter that you just started playing, if you get there you will be helped back up by fellow strangers.
- Quite linear gameplay.
- Huge map to explore, expect to die if you venture too far (won't lose anything, though).
Cons:
- DLCs. Expect to get mad if you don't want to pay anything for this game, you can get good weapons, but you will get very good weapons that require DLCs.
- The grinding: you will be able to pay for your stuff (such as weapons and aesthetic armor), but if not, then expect to grind A LOT.
- Far too ammo friendly, you'll never run out of bullets.

reviewText:
Meh, it's not terrible but it's not great either.

I spent a good half an hour travelling to the next part of the mission campaign, half an hour of driving. Now you might think that sounds enjoyable but it was not, it was boring. Scattered across the map are some optional minigames which are okay, but I just got bored and the missions seem to drag on a bit too long.

However, this game has some pretty decent graphics for an MMO, so if you've got some expensive hardware you might enjoy this game's looks. The PVP is alright, it wasn't special, if you've played some of the other PVP modes in games like Tomb Raider and (insert another generic triple A here) you'll know what to expect.

All in all it's a typical F2P with a tonne of microtransactions, if you want to change your look it's gonna cost you, if you want a different coloured quad bike it'll cost you some of that moolah.

reviewText:
I really don't understand all the negative reviews. I think this is a great game, I enjoy it very much. Easy to start, you can play only 20 minutes if you like. And it's free, you know. You really can easily put 100 hours in and still enjoy it, for FREE. I bought the season pass anyways, it's just costs as much as a normal game would.
I like that there are short and long mission, big events with about a hundred players, you can hop in for only a few minutes or take part in hour long events.
I've played about 140 hours now and haven't ever felt that I need to put real money in the game. I bought the season pass DLCs only out of respect for the developers, and still didn't finish all the mission in them.
Locations and events are kind of repetitive and reused a lot, but every now and then I change my gear and gameplay changes a lot with a new type of gun.
So, I think the game is worth trying and putting in the first 5-10 hours of getting the feel of the game. Anyways, the best part starts when you get to the second big location, to your 3rd fast travel point.

reviewText: Defiance... If you enjoy an open world, free roam, multi-mission, mmo, rpg style, guns, pvp, coop, welllllll daaang! The list will keep on going. To me this game is like Firefall/Warframe. A mix of Borderlands classic looks for vehicles, armors, and weapons. Ark Falls as you level up prove more challenging and drop goods from beginning to the end of every battle. The game seems to go with your pace of leveling. So however you play in any game, will reflect on how quickly you level, gain awesome mods, weapons and more. Along with areas showing more side missions than you know what to do with. Group up with 1 to many people or run like a lone wolf. You like racing? Alone? This game has it... putting you up against the world of players on the leaderboards. PVP your style? Defiance has got it! Mind you this game has its bugs, quirks and lag points. Like with any game you find yourself immerced in an open world of gliches and lag spikes along with a rich world of never ending adventures! So with that, hope to see y'all on the battlefields of Defiance! ~D (Admiral Hawke - Defiance)(Now, NSI-DiabolicaHawke, Founder of NSI Nothing Stops Insanity)

reviewText:
I've only played Defiance for about an hour now, but I'm already well into downloading this game patch, and I feel I know the game well enough to write up a review.

Defiance is a neat data entry simulator where you go to http://orcz.com/Defiance:_Arkfall_Codes and enter 120 of those codes into the Defiance website. Once you've done that, you've won the game! :D

You can continue patching after you've beaten the game. I guess that's like new game plus or something. Right now I'm making a neat Minecraft village while the patch continues. You should see it; it's pretty cool.

In conclusion, I would recommend Minecraft for anyone looking to make tiny forts while stuff downloads. :3

reviewText:
Have you ever played a kind of bad game then still play it for some reason? This is one of those games.

This MMO is set in the future. Humanity was forced to have literal illegal aliens migrate to their planet and technology greatly prospered. But however, there is one faction that is like so damn xenophobic. It is the Dark Matter. Dark Matter are these cool looking space xenophobes who make up the alien races that came from the collection of illegals.

Honestly, I think my favorite MMO villains are the Dark Matter. Plus, they have giant robots.

Pros:

PvP is easy as hell. Just get a radioactive SMG and a grenade launcher. I once got this amazing score by blowing up almost the entire enemy force. They all cloaked and for some reason decided to go in this corridor where I was. I had the sneaking suspicion that I was being looked at so I fired a couple of grenades and detonated them. Got a couple of kills so I proceeded to then just blow the HELL out of that corridor and got more kills. Explosion simulator 10/10

The enemies are pretty cool. First we have cybernetic miners who for some reason are very hostile. Next we have mutants. The mutants are a huge threat. They seek to invade D6 like their communist brethern. Woops, wrong game but still...they're pretty much a threat. And finally, we have these giant space armored guys who for some reason remind me of something that I can't even think about. Oh, right! They remind me of the Combine Empire. We also have these space robots who basically robotify you from inside-out. Scary as hell.


Cons:

The Loot System has some problems. For some odd reason the game reminds us of Borderlands yet there isn't any notice-able gun variety.

The quests are very dull at a certain point.

Reputations are easy/hard to acquire for some reason to me.

My 100% organically grown oranges disapprove of the cons. Ergo, it is a con.

The Final Verdict:

This game has that weird attraction. It most likely will attract you back if you think about it.

Anyways, this game is recommended if you just want to have fun. Believe me if you will, this game is as easy as cooking Meth in PAYDAY 2.

reviewText:
The gameplay is okay, if you're willing to shell out the money for every expansion. Be aware it's pay2win. PvP is impossible to contest unless you drop $100+. PvE is where the game focuses on. But again there will be a lot of loot you're unable to use without the expansions.

The absolute most annoying thing is the newest update. There is an item in game called a cyber rig. It allows you to enhance your style of gameplay. The issue is unless if you're willing to pay the company money, you will not be able to get this item except for 3 times a week. Even if you're successful on the missions, its still only a chance. If you fall in battle it cost another token to continue.

Horrible way to make the cyber rig in the game and giving yet another way for pay2win players an advantage in PvP.

reviewText: TL;DR:  Worth picking up if you find it on sale.\n\nThis game pleasantly surprised me.  I managed to pick it up on Steam Summer Sale for 50% off.  It gets -slightly- repetitive while levelling, but no where near as much as most MMO / Grindfests.  It mixes MMO / 3rd-Person Shooter exceptionally well, and it doesn't try to force you to work with people (you can run through the entire storyline solo).  It's multiplayer offers several different modes of PvP combat, Co-Op missions, and a Rift-Like system called Arks".  You are an Ark-Hunter
recommended: and choosing to  help your fellow players in these big (sometimes massive) battles is rewarding both visually and inventorily.\n\nAlso
hoursPlayed: Vehicles!  In an mmo.  Summonable
voteText: like mounts
helpfulPercent: but vehicles!  And they act properly like vehicles.  That's almost a miracle.\n\nAll of that said
votesHelpful: this game is still pretty easy to put down.  Despite everything I like about it
votesTotal: I don't think I would be nearly as happy with the game if I had paid full price.  For everything it does that is unique
votesFunny: there are 2 other things copy and pasted from previous MMO's.  I suppose that's to be expected.\n\nThe characters can be a little dry at times
commentsCount: but the storyline is solid.  Character creation is GREAT for a FPS
column16: and Lacking for an MMO.\n\nBuy it if it's on sale.  It's worth it.  I don't recommend paying full price."

reviewText:
games pros

*weapons feel nice a fair amount of them and can be customized but the lack of shotguns being effective in pve (imo) puts a dent on 3 of the weapon classes

*story kinda good makes you hate a charecter which is always nice

*big raid like events that just happen without any setup

*dungeons all be it limited amount of them

*you can join your friends no matter what level you are (bar some dungeons) but a lv 10 isent much less powerfull than a lv 5000

*chalanges side quests and lotsa little things to keep you distracted

*solid 3rd person shooting and looks quite pretty to boot

*can make a party to meetup with your friends the bigest downer on this is its only a 4 person party i belive which it would be nice to see something that would allow larger groups of players to be grouped together such as a raid group or similer or simply 2 groups saying hey lets group up our groups?



Game cons

*side quest suck REALY REALY BADLY SUCK generic go fetch this because yoloswag ile pay you something useless

*arkfalls while fun get boring quite fast and dont have the sence of omg im needed here unlike if your used to playing a tanking or healing role in other mmos

*weapons shair ammo types i dont think this is a downside but since it cant be labeled as an upside it gos here

*cash shop nuff said (tho they dont have many things that can aid the player charecter most things are just for looks)

*not very good dlc even tho its cheep its not realy that worth it if you just wanna play the game as most all things can be done without and the dlcs mainly give new weapons

*if your comeing into this alown i would imagine it would be a boring exsperience i came into it with a few friends and it was realy fun but from the times ive played solo the only things that keep you playing are the chalanges once you lose the buzz of leveling because it becomes meaningless.


All in all good game got atleast 10 hours of play if your just zoomin around on a quad and haveing fun and quite alot more if your a compleationist going for all the chalanges but for new players be very wary of the dlc as it doesent seem to add alot but the standard game i can happily recomend and thank you for putting up with all the spelling and grammar mistakes XD

reviewText:
I figure I'll add to the positive reviews and outline good features others missed.

My friends and I all play and level up at different paces.  In every other MMO that's a big problem because eventually level differences mean you can no longer play together or further advanced players have to replay crap to help the lower level friends level up.  I usually stop playing an MMO once I no longer have any friends who are at a level I can party with and they generally do the same.  It gets real boring playing with strangers you have no intention in forming any meaningful relationships with so I generally avoid that.  This game solves that delimma by temporarily boosting lower level players to just a small margin of difference of the highest level players in a group.  Lower level players will have more of a challenge, but will not find it impossible as they would in other MMOs.

Wherever you go, the enemy mobs are dynamically adjusted to match the level of the highest player in the area, that combined with the low level players getting boosted means everybody everywhere has to play with skill, and can't just blow through everything with overpowered weapons.  Since leveling up unlocks perks, skills, rewards and generally more powerful weapons, it's still very much worth leveling up in spite of the auto-balancing.

While there is no in-game system for quest sharing, you can still accompany anybody doing a quest that you've already done before and see the cut scenes again and at least get the exp.  The game has no problems with both players doing the same exact quest at the same time though, you just have to make sure all players manually start it.  Again, it will still be a challenge for all no matter what your level or what the level gap between party members.

This feature also fixes another problem many MMOs have.  A lot of people like myself tend to explore and side-quest.  In so many MMOs, I would explore so much that by the time I got back on a main story mission, it would be boring and unchallenging due to how much stronger my character was over the requirements for that quest.  This game ensures you can play however you want and not be punished by unchallenging quests whenever you finally get to them.

The game has a cash shop built in that existed even before free to play.  This was due to the fact that there was never a monthly fee for this game.  You only had to buy the client.  Now the client is free and that's the only thing that's changed.  People tend to fear that a game going to the f2p model ruins it, but this game was already sort of free to play.  It just had an entry fee that was recently waived.  I can only see that as a huge plus.  The cash shop tends to sell a few perks, but nothing that I've seen to give the players an unfair advantage against the environment or other players.  Just things like faster leveling, more inventory, nicer looking vehicles, alternate costumes and random item crates.  The random item crates may be pushing it, but they never give paying players anything that regular players can't obtain and since it's a gamble that may yield crappy results, I don't see players with deep pockets abusing it that much to any sort of advantage.

Another thing for me would be to speak to the DLC aspect.  It turns out that most of the DLC items can be obtained and used by players that don't even own the DLC if you're lucky enough to get one from a tier 4 lockbox (obtainable in game without spending real cash).  Also, when a DLC purchaser unlocks a DLC area in the overworld (ie: calling down an arkfall), even non-DLC players can enter.  There just won't be any any DLC drops in there for those players.  Only normal drops.

Oh yeah, did I forget to mention drops are instanced?  Well they are.  Nobody ever has to fight over goodies again.  It also ensures drops match the level of the player so everybody gets something useful to them.

What does all of this add up to?  The creators of this game basically created a balanced way for all players to partake in any of the game's very challenging, rewarding, and extremely fun random events that happen in the overworld.  It's extremely common to go to the site of a major arkfall and find about 50 to 150 other players teaming up to hold off a hoard of monsters or defat a major boss.  There's no need for a instancing system or queueing system thanks to the auto-balancing which just keeps things so fluid it's crazy.

It never fails to be fun.

reviewText: Let me start off by saying that Defiance gets more of a bad wrap than it deserves. Let me just get the negatives out of the way first. It's true the game is far from perfect, and there are better MMOs out there. It's also true that it is basically a watered-down Borderlands. With the upcoming switch to f2p for the game, as a Deluxe Edition early buyer, I'm more than a bit disappointed, and I feel that loyal players deserve more than what Trion is giving them after this change. It's sad that after already having to buy things in the cash shop from the very beginning, the players that paid 60 dollars for the game still aren't getting completely compensated when all they are giving them are a few extra inventory slots and a few character slots. Character slots should be unlimited for those that bought the game in my opinion, and the game needs to increase its inventory slots overall, because the number you were given pretty much made you want to buy the expansion in the cash shop long before the game went f2p. Now that I got that out of the way and off my chest, I will tell you why this game is very dear to my heart.\n\nThe TV show is extremely entertaining and is a great show. The events from the game that tie into the show make you feel like you are part of the world's history, and that is a good thing. Furthermore, it is rare to find an MMO with a storyline, and this game does this extremely well using cutscenes. Defiance isn't genre defining, but it's definitely a fresh take on the gameplay from Borderlands, as the first game to be connected with an on-going summer TV series. It's kind of fun to have an MMO version of Borderlands, which I always felt like Borderlands felt like an MMO without players. The game has had a few glitches here-and-there, but nothing really game-breaking has ever occured in the many-many hours I've spent playing this game. The characters in this game are charming and memorable, which is more than you could say for the characters in the vast majority of MMOs. The cutscenes allow characters to express personality, and the voice actors do a good job of breathing life into the NPCs. As far as MMOs go, I could see if the hate towards this game was because of the always-existing cash shop, but most of the hate seems to be directed at the gameplay. The gameplay is not bad, it just needs a tad bit more polish. This game is worth giving a chance. While it may not be for everyone, enough players have fallen in love with the game's charm to allow it to survive this long despite the struggle to keep players interested. The TV show is doing fairly well, and hopefully by going f2p, this will allow people to experience the game and see what has charmed so many people into sticking with a game that often gets more negative reviews than it deserves. The game sets out what it intended to do for the most part, but as of right now, there are no incentives to play as the other races, so hopefully specialty missions will be added in the future. If you only intend to play through the story of the game, you have nothing to lose. It isn't a bad game, and deserves more love than it gets.

reviewText:
I'm gonna go with a pros and cons type review so here it is

pros:
-There is a variety of missions, side missions, races and rampages
-Many guns(YES)
-Vehicles and if you are too lazy, quick transports
-Nice (but not too detailed) character creation (not the best but still nice)
-You actually need to level different kinda weapons to level up so you get to experience different combat styles
-You can choose between various voices for your character
-Team work isn't necessary unless you need to do co-op maps
-PvP is challenging(which is a necessity)
-Missions to level up make you experience different sides of the game

Cons:
-Help desk isn't very useful (it hasn't been for me at least)
-Team work can suck because of certain player types
-You can pay to be superior to other players
-The game starts to repeat itself after a while especially once you have done the main missions
-Buggy

So all in all, you can enjoy yourself playing the game but get ready for the rocky parts of the road.

reviewText: Played it for a while. It's a pretty good game altogether, but not my taste. I prefer shooters where cover and headshots really impact the game, but this game does neither. Sure, headshots give double damage, but the enemy still needs 30 shots to go down. I can see how many people would like this game, but I personally don't. I'm giving it a positive review because I think it's very solid, good lore, good enemies, nice variety of weapons, impressive online experience (playing with others actually increases enjoyability, which is rare in mmo shooters nowadays), massive world to explore and a pleasing visual art style. I dislike it personally due to a lack of direction at the beginning, as I came for a mount promotion from another game, and I dislike how the interactions with npc work (stale animations, almost no cutscenes, straightup lame characters at times) and having a hard time to find places for me to level have made this game a bit cringy to me. I advice you to play it nontheless, because I think people could enjoy this enough to sink a quick 300 hours into it.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Pros -
Borderlands MMO
Vehicles spawn near you, not at terminals
Presets for different weapon sets / Specs
Interesting Spec trees that interconnect
No set class system
Vehicles are affordable
Rifts and events form across map
PvP is available (sometimes unpopulated though)
Dying isn't punishing in relocation in most cases
Gear is cosmetic and presetable with your weapon set ups
Similar grenade and weapon effects with Borderlands (IE: Fire, Acid, Electric, Sludge>Frost)
F2P

Cons -
Ego Levels" from 1-6000 makes gameplay repetitive
Character customization is lacking (No gear coloring system either)
High tier weapon effects make PvP one sided early game
Early game instancing quests requires lengthy hide and seek with PvE Mobs if RNGod allows Mobs shots to hit repeatidly (Depending on your spec and weapon / shield level)
Playerbase is noticeably less than mainstream MMOs
Cash shop sells epic loot boxes
Certain items you loot may require DLC"

reviewText:
Despite what it says, I only played 3 or 4 hours. I was AFK for the other time.

Game started good.
-Good graphics
-Decent controls
-Random drops (which I like)
-Skill moves

But then... I got to the season 2 and saw what I think are HUGE flaws/nuisances
-Unlockable fast travel (visit place first)
-Extremely long drives
-Weak weapons
-Powerful enemies
-Annoying voice repetition

I could deal with the unlockable fast travel, fine. I could deal with the driving, whatever. I could not deal with the fact that it is insanely hard to do things alone. I understand that events are meant to be done with other players, but even the main story missions become ludicrously hard in SEASON 2. Just...why? WHY did the make the game so hard that it REQUIRES friends? WHY did they make it so you can't get away from enemies due to lack of cover? WHY did they make the game a ball of rage? I don't know, but I wouldn't recommend the game unless you like extremely hard third-person shooters. This brings me to think that, despite the game having what I thought was a good start and good base ideas, it just brings too much fury into the combat to make it fun.
Rating: 5/10 Average

reviewText: Defiance is great for what it is, Giant monsters and fun guns. Wouldn't say the story line is the best, however if you are looking for a casual game to play with some friends that just want to run around and kill giant monsters with a large number of other players, this is the game for you. However if you are looking for a game to be the one MMO you play for a long time you may want to look elsewhere as sometimes the game gets fairly repetetive by doing alot of Arkfalls. They seem to release new content fairly often as well. Overall, I'd say pick it up with some friends, its well worth the low price.

reviewText:
Defiance is that co-op game you’ve been looking for to play with all your friends or family members.  The co-op is very easy to get into and if you want to play on your own you can but it’s just as easy to join other players to clear some missions.

The environment in Defiance is beautiful and even with fast travel available I mostly only use it to sell/buy things at the shops because driving around is just so much fun to do with all the jumps, hills, cliffs and a stunning environment that you just never know what you’ll run into, and sometimes that just happens to be the face of a mutant while your speeding off a cliff at 90 miles per hour. Ark falls are a lot of fun to do, and most of the time for the bigger ark falls there is about 40 people vs a giant monster, it’s almost like a rave party except one with bullets, lasers beams, and explosives, and afterwards everyone gets to go home with an big bag full of goodies and sometimes even some rare item drops.

Defiance really reminds me of borderlands in some ways, and in many ways I've enjoyed it more than borderlands 2 personally. Defiance is really like a combination of Borderlands, Mass Effect, and some kind of amazing off road racing game. Defiance doesn’t really give us anything new, ground breaking, or revolutionary but it does deliver a solid top notch game and will provide you with many hours of entertainment. If you haven’t given the game a chance yet, go for it, it’s only 9$ and it’s a lot of fun. Although defiance is really fun, it isn’t perfect and does its fair share of bugs and glitches like this one glitch were I couldn’t finish a mission no matter how many time I tried to redo it, until the next day I was able to complete it without an issue, With that said don’t be scared off or be too worried as that is a rare occurrence and most of the time corrects itself so you can avoid giving birth to an elephant in extreme rage and go off chaseing some arkfalls or play some other missions untill its avalible.

Pros:

-	It only costs 9$ and with no subscription fee
-	Amazing Co-Op (or Solo gaming if that’s your thing)
-	Replay ability
-	Beautiful environment
-	Good Story
-	Driving mechanics and vehicles
-	Smooth Gameplay
-	Cinematics and voice over are well done for an MMO
-	Open world

Cons:

-	The odd Bugs and glitches
-	Could use more instruction for new players at times
-	Pick up’s can be a bit over whelming for new players
-	No ability to store items
-	Repetition

Over all on a scale from 1 to 10 I would give the game 8.5 Out of 10.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A decent multiplayer third person shooter, somewhat reminiscent of Borderlands in terms of the skill system and loot. The MMO aspect isn't something you'll see a lot of, many missions are instanced and most competitive PvP stuff puts the players on separate maps.\nThe story is, somewhat surprisingly considering it's based on a TV show, not particularly intriguing, the mission get somewhat stale after a while, but the setting - the overgrown United States after a failed alien terraforming attempt, is interesting in concept. As game mechanics go, it's solid for the genre, and it does get pretty cool when you team up with a bunch of other players to take on the timed world events. The player base has started waning at this point though, and other than the major arkfall events you'll rarely come across any larger crowds. At this point I would not recommend the DLC, they just barely provide what was promised in the season pass description, mostly coming down to a few new weapon types and missions, all taking place at the already existing land mass from the core game. Unless the specific weapon types in the DLC description seem to suit your preferred play style (I did like the charge weapons added with the first DLC), you'll probably not get much out of them.\nAs for the game itself, it's not charging a subscription, and I haven't found the need to use any of the stuff available in the microtransaction store (which mostly boil down to limited time XP gains, random weapon packs - which are very easy to get with the in-game currency - and some costumes), it's pretty solid at what it tries to do, but not as ambitious as you would hope hearing the talk about an MMO third person shooter. At the asked price point I think the base game is definitely worth it, but I'd hold off on the DLC until a sale.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Defiance is a solid third person multiplayer shooter that I continue to enjoy, the weapons, shooting mechanics and driving are fluid and the storyline is enjoyable.

However once you have completed the story you will have to grind arkfalls and other dynamic events in order to obtain keycodes which in turn can give you access to the Tier 4 Lockboxes which the endgame boils down random chances for gun progression. Due to the many different rolls on weapons there is a low chance to receive your ideal weapon.

There is never enough information presented to the player and the UI is clearly designed for consoles. Several of the graphical options are limited in order to work on consoles. The chat system was patched to work several months after launch. The same 5 open world zones get pretty repetetive after a while, but there is a 6th zone coming out shortly.

reviewText: From what I have played so far, I can say I really like this game. There are cutscenes for main missions, if you are into that sort of RP, however your character does not speak. Most people that I have come across are willing to help you with a mission, especially if you are in the same proximity as their quest. Starting off very early you are granted a vehicle which you can use to get places faster, so you do not have to spend real money to get a vehicle. Never going to pay a cent to play this game (or so I think), but I am not having problems buying/finding better weapons as I earn in-game currency for completing quests. Have not queued for any PVP since that is not my thing, but I would assume it wouldn't be bad. I will update this review as I play more

reviewText:
TLDR: This game is basically a more serious, online version of borderlands, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. Its free so it's definitely worth the time to download and have a play around.

The main problem i have with the game could be summed up by a description of one fight. I was doing a story mission, running around a ranch shooting raiders. so far so good. I then saw a miniboss on a nearby rooftop, so i pull out my sniper rifle, and shoot him in the head. his health bar stays the same but the damage readout says 4000 damage. i empty the rest of the clip into his head. not only is he still standing, his health bar is almost full. So, skip to the sixtieth headshot i get on him, and i've run out of ammo. i pull out a light machine gun and close in. five hundred rounds later, he's at 60% health. i'm not quite out of ammo but he has been spamming grenades all around me and now there's nowhere for me to go that doesn't have a detonating grenade. i get one-shot and go into bleedout. i revive myself and run behind a building.i see an ammo crate, refill my ammo, and ~150 headshots later he dies.

So my problem is that enemies are far too bulletsponge-y. A basic, unarmoured bandit, with no helmet, will often take two, three or four headshots from a sniper rifle, or dozens of point blank headshots from an assault rifle, SMG, LMG etc.

This, combined with the fact that enemies will just keep spawning faster than you can fill them with bullets means tht the gunplay is a bit of a letdown. quite a big problem, as a lot of mission objectives involve 'interact with this object for five seconds without taking damage' objetcives, meaning you either cheese it with cloak, or you spend 5-10 minutes in the same area just mindlessly killing the same enemies over and over again until you've got a five second window. Fast-spawning mobs would be fine, if they died quickly. bulletsponges would be fine if they were finite, which wouldn't really work in an MMO. sadly, this means that you can snipe everyone in an area, walk up to the objective and find that there was really no point because the enemies have respawned already and you're stuck in the same close quarters battle anyway.

Aside from that, it is a good game. the fact it was originally not free to play means that the microtransactions aren't built in from the ground up to be 'necessary', vehicles are actually vehicles, not mounts, and you can do some fun stuff with the jet-booster quadbike you get half an hour into the game

reviewText:
Haven't played too much but it was worth the download. It's a shooter meets MMO.

Things to know
- You can run out of ammo and you need to know how to aim.
- Tutorial sucks so look up how to roll and crouch.
- The starting weapon is only that, you can use any weapon you find so pick your background based on what looks cool or you like the idea of. You aren't trapped to one weapon.
- The main ability u pick seems to unequip after you learn it, so hit L and click on it and look for an equip button on the bottem of the screen.
- Main abilities seem to dictate playstyles, don't pick cloak if you want to be brute force.
- Playstyle meaning things related to that will be selectable perks.
- The Main abilities are Stealth/Killing power ranged/Misdirection and Movement killing power melee. There are melee enemies that will get up in your face so the last one certainly is a valid playstyle.

It's fun and fast gameplay and it's free.

reviewText:
A very neat game that suffers horribly from lag and latency issues.

In a sentence: MMO Borderlands.

The good: Open-ended world where every event is scaled down to your (and level of those who are with you) level. Almost right away you get a ride! Free to roam everywhere. Great concept!

The bad: Unfortunately not as great of a scenario campaign, and open world doesn't add much to a railroad script. Everything is competitive so cooperation isn't really encouraged. You would think twice about deploying damage booster in a middle of a crowd of other players, because it gives +100% damage to everyone within it's radius. Bonuses/items received at the end of the mission are based on what you placed in a ladder of everyone who attempted that mission with you.

The ugly: would not recommend. Mission progress is not tracked, and it is very possible to get DC due to lag, halfway through an hour long mission. Very frustrating.

reviewText: Pretty good game! I didnt expect to like it and yet here I find myself wanting to play it. Definitely gets harder as you play, especially when you get to missions where there's nobody to help you out. The creatures you fight are constantly changing. There's so much action going on in this game, you'll be on you way to the next mission in the main story and pass straight through an arkfall and two episode missions, it's pretty cool. You can always just drop what you're doing and help people out with the missions that they're on if you really wanted to. It's completely open world and there are so many different weapons and perks. It's kinda like Borderlands, but without the comic book graphics. I can't really think of any downfalls to this game, I haven't seen any glitches or experienced anything that made me wanna rage quit yet. So it's definitely worth trying!
